text: The for sure carry is more informative in the cross section. If we're building a multi-asset carry portfolio, it's going to have a sharp north of one. Just operating in simulation space, it's going to be well north of one. And trend is going to be more like 0.8. So for sure carry is the cat's meow in terms of building those cross-sectional portfolios. When you put trend and carry together, though, the impact is pretty profound, right? Risk goes down quite a bit. Return doesn't really fall. And then your question of how much value added is there in the timing, the dynamic component, doing more carry in this asset class versus that, more turn in this asset class versus that at any point in time. You're right that those are sort of icy on the cake rather than the main drivers of performance. That said, there are times when it's very meaningful and where intuition cannot support having meaningful exposure to carry in an asset class. And where if you're just operating systematically and allocating constant risk to an asset class slash factor cell in the matrix, you're going to have this meaningful risk exposure, something that doesn't make any sense. So we still think it's better and makes more sense to go where the carry is when you're doing carry. So we really, when we think about building our carry portfolio, we've got a one-shot portfolio construction. But within each asset class, we're normalizing relative to the middle of carry over risk. And so that carry portfolio is market neutral in each asset class. But the preponderance of the risk exposure goes where the carry is.

segments.text: The for sure carry is more informative in the cross section.
If we're building a multi-asset carry portfolio, it's going to have a sharp north of one.
Just operating in simulation space, it's going to be well north of one.
And trend is going to be more like 0.8.
So for sure carry is the cat's meow in terms of building those cross-sectional portfolios.
When you put trend and carry together, though, the impact is pretty profound, right?
Risk goes down quite a bit.

And then your question of how much value added is there in the timing, the dynamic component, doing more carry in this asset class versus that, more turn in this asset class versus that at any point in time.
You're right that those are sort of icy on the cake rather than the main drivers of performance.
That said, there are times when it's very meaningful and where intuition cannot support having meaningful exposure to carry in an asset class.

And where if you're just operating systematically and allocating constant risk to an asset class slash factor cell in the matrix, you're going to have this meaningful risk exposure, something that doesn't make any sense.
So we still think it's better and makes more sense to go where the carry is when you're doing carry.
So we really, when we think about building our carry portfolio, we've got a one-shot portfolio construction.
But within each asset class, we're normalizing relative to the middle of carry over risk.
And so that carry portfolio is market neutral in each asset class.
But the preponderance of the risk exposure goes where the carry is.
